items.title: Put Object Limit / Write Limits
items.body:
Is anyone aware of any limitations that the minio client would have using `fput_object` if used in a multithread process? My service uses multithreading to download multiple images from s3 and in the function it is supposed to upload it to our local minio server.

I get a lot of success confirmations in the console, but when I go to check if the file exists, it does not. I suspect that the minio sdk or server cannot handle many writes at once.

Has anyone experienced this issue?

items.title: Minio 6.0 no longer includes config*sample
items.body: Since the configuration sample files were moved from the credentials directory to test/unit, MANIFEST.in was not updated to include them in the sdist.

items.title: minio set_bucket_notification gives error "InvalidArgument: message"
[not our bug] Receiving Bad Request when calling MINIO Server from minio/api.py (
items.body:
Hello.

I am working with @vsoch  on an SREGISTRY integration that uses MINIO for the storage backend with HTTPS/SSL enabled.

The environment (for testing/development) is a couple containers on a single host and looks like this:

Where the GREEN Container is our running instance of MINIO and the Two containers in purple are our MINIO clients that implement / instantiate two instances of MinioClient on startup _(as i will outline below)_

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9358276/88952485-83069d00-d265-11ea-81a8-bdb5db7df382.png)

A bit about our minio installation

Here is the docker-compose that is in use - you can see we consuming the .mino-env  on startup
- we also have done the appropriate SSL certificate (with the .PEM consisting our of cert+intermediate and the key the key)
-  "know" this works, since we can see the following when we do a a simple "curl" from linux (since a browser test might be helped by baked in intermediates) we get the following (i have redacted some of our personal info)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9358276/88961811-89037a80-d273-11ea-8852-b534a2fa8e61.png)


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9358276/88953340-cad9f400-d266-11ea-8990-983877fdcb5b.png)

When we login to the MINIO Web UI, we can see the following:
 - we see that SSL/HTTP is working (Browser wise)  (UI-pic1 below)
 - we are able to see that we can create new Containers and they are written back down the backing filesystem (UI-pic2-1, UI-PIC2-2,  and TERM-SHOT-1 of the filesystem after i created)

UI-PIC-1
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9358276/88953895-8c910480-d267-11ea-969e-2fac87896cc3.png)


UI-PIC-2-1
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9358276/88953623-302de500-d267-11ea-942a-acb34ed13def.png)

UI-PIC-2-2
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9358276/88953747-5e132980-d267-11ea-8f76-da0d54142388.png)

TERM-SHOT-1
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9358276/88953997-b518fe80-d267-11ea-8a87-344ba67847f7.png)

As well, here is the "mc config ls" output to show our setup defined

MC-LS-1

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9358276/88954197-fad5c700-d267-11ea-9e6f-c6e0f2153904.png)


So we are pretty sure that the HTTPS action to/from MINIO is 'ok" from a certificate point of view.

In the SREGISTRY instantion of the two minio clients, we have the following code bit (and this is where we are seeing the "BadRequest failure "  - note that we create two clients, one for External Access - which is HTTPS://ourfdqn as shown and there is another that is to use the internal link  - minio - which would resolve on the docker "links" (we are not using a seperate brigde as docker in the docker compose above to link the client containers to the minio container).  the idea being that the sregistries are trusted and thus would not implement https.  However, it seems that with the secure=TRUE/FALSE, flag we end up in a situation where minio is bringing up a endpoint called https://127.0.0.1:9000.

[root@grid-singregistry-master sregistry]# docker logs -f 401a3d72a310
Attempting rotation of encrypted config, IAM users and policies on MinIO with newly supplied credentials
Rotation complete, please make sure to unset MINIO_ACCESS_KEY_OLD and MINIO_SECRET_KEY_OLD envs
Endpoint:  https://172.17.0.4:9000  https://127.0.0.1:9000



The issue here is that for me to "make this work" i would need to put a SAN in our cert for 127.0.0.1. 

CLIENT-CODE-SNIP-1

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9358276/88961562-32963c00-d273-11ea-97b3-e8b98a0c150d.png)


CLIENT-STACK-TRACE-1

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9358276/88954709-c9a9c680-d268-11ea-90a0-981bdbf8f9b5.png)


From what i have understood, is that when we instantiate the minioClient call( either the internal or the External one) there is a connection, so im a bit stumped as to why this is failed with BadRequest on the if not makebucket command.

You will notice above that the exception shows a minioExternalClient call, that is from me trying both types of clients to see if there is anything instantiated.

I did a TCPDUMP on port 9000 on the NIC that hold the docker bridge and container traffic and no request on port 9000 ever arrived during any startup, so i suspect that the instantiation is failing of the client, but im not sure how to further in minio.py figure out if its cause of a SSL/non SSL mix up (our idea is that all communications shall be over HTTPS (internal or external as we start to distribute it).

Perhaps a silly configuration i am missing with the secure flag for the clients?

Any help would be much appreciated.
D

items.title: Python Minio  set_bucket_notification()  in Minio S3 Sandbox
items.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->
This is related to the issue - Set notification namespace for NotificationConfiguration minio/minio#6789 . The set_bucket_notification() is not working in Python as expected when using minio sandbox (play.minio.io). 
 I'm using docker minio client and server. Could anyone let me know whether this function works in Python?

## Expected Behavior
When I use set_bucket_notification() in Minio Python SDK, it should work. However, getting an error.
`from minio import Minio
from minio.error import (ResponseError, SignatureDoesNotMatch, BucketAlreadyOwnedByYou,
                         BucketAlreadyExists)


# Initialize minioClient with an endpoint and access/secret keys.
minioClient = Minio('play.minio.io',
               access_key='Q3AM3UQ867SPQQA43P2F',
               secret_key='zuf+tfteSlswRu7BJ86wekitnifILbZam1KYY3TG'
 )
print("Connection successful")
notification = {
    'CloudFunctionConfigurations': [
        {
            'Arn': 'arn1',
            'Events': ['s3:ObjectCreated:*'],
            'Filter': {
                'Key': {
                    'FilterRules': [
                        {
                            'Name': 'suffix',
                            'Value': '.xml'
                        }
                    ]
                }
            }
           # 'CloudFunction': 'http://localhost:8000/testapi'
        }
    ]
}
try:
    minioClient.set_bucket_notification('testbucket', notification)
except ResponseError as err:
    # handle error response from service.
    print(err)`


## Current Behavior
Currently, using set_bucket_notification() in Minio Python SDK, gives an error. Below is the error msg.
`ResponseError: code: UnsupportedNotification, message: MinIO server does not support Topic or Cloud Function based notifications., bucket_name: otdatahub, object_name: None, request_id: xxx, host_id: yyy, region:`


## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)

1. Run the below code which uses set_bucket_notification() in Minio Python SDK.

2. You will get an error.

## Your Environment
<!--- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->
* Version used (`minio --version`): Using the latest docker minio client
* Server setup and configuration: Using the latest docker minio client
* Operating System : MAC OS

items.title: AWS IAM provider fails to renew token upon expiration
items.body:
The AWS IAM provider adds a 5 minute time delta to the actual expiration time of the token provided by AWS.

https://github.com/minio/minio-py/blob/99dd78b3a44a9ad2c5fb636b2c0de18ef7b3a82a/minio/credentials/providers.py#L236

This causes a 5 minute period of time in which the SDK is operating with expired credentials before asking for a new token.

items.title: Serious memory leak on multipart file upload
items.body:
Hello,

it looks like there is a series memory leak while uploading multipart files to s3 using this client. We use version 5.0.10 of it and were observing constant pod crashes due to OutOfMemory exceptions while uploading bigger files to S3. This is particularly visible if the allocated amount of pod memory resources is low. After some investigation we've figured out the root cause of the issue might be in https://github.com/minio/minio-py/blob/c8aaeba8f25579aa9bc161ddede9691017c1c42b/minio/api.py#L1734:

```
        for part_number in range(1, total_parts_count + 1):
            current_part_size = (part_size if part_number < total_parts_count
                                 else last_part_size)

            part_data = read_full(data, current_part_size)
            pool.add_task(self._upload_part_routine, (
                bucket_name, object_name, upload_id, part_number, part_data,
                sse, progress))
```

In this loop we load the data from the source and put the chunks into the pool. The actual cause is the `part_data = read_full(data, current_part_size)` line. We, actually, load all the chunks into RAM first (even for very big files) and pass these memory chunks into corresponding upload threads. I assume the expected behaviour should be that the data should be read into the memory from the inside of each thread. This way only the "active" chunks will be loaded into RAM when the pool decides to activate the particular thread (according to its `max_workers` setting). 

Some local debugging to illustrate the issue better:

items.title: Accessing Minio Azure Gateway through Apache Reverse Proxy
items.body:
I have a minio azure gateway running on kubernetes.  I access the instance through an apache reverse proxy.  It is secured via self generated certificates.  I am able to access the minio instance via the web and do not receive a warning after importing the root cert.  I am able to login, create, and delete buckets, and the changes persist between tear downs of the kubernetes instances.

The issue I have is connecting with the python client.  When attempting to connect with secure enabled, I get the error:

`minio.error.SignatureDoesNotMatch: SignatureDoesNotMatch: message: The request signature we calculated does not match the signature you provided.`

I did some more research and found the recipe on the minio website for a minio http proxy:

(https://docs.min.io/docs/setup-apache-http-proxy-with-minio-server.html)

I've followed this example, specifically adding `ProxyPreserveHost On` and the signature error goes away.  However, if I try to make a bucket or check if a bucket exists, I get bad results.  In the case of making a bucket I get an error saying the bucket does not exist.  If I check if a bucket exists, I get a `False` even though the bucket actually exists.  I believe this is due to 404s being returned and being incorrectly interpreted by the python client as a legitimate result.

Overall, I am stumped why the web version works flawlessly but I am unable to get the python client to work.  Any debugging ideas or thoughts would be appreciated.

items.title: IamEc2MetaData slows down get operations with anonymus access
items.body:
## Problem description

When trying to access a bucket anonymusy, the `IamEc2MetaData` class slows down the process if the target **hard coded** endpoint is not reachable or returns some error. That adds about 4.5 min overhead to a single request in my case.

## Steps to reproduce

1. Start the minio server docker:
```
docker run -p 9000:9000 --name minio minio/minio server /data
```
2. Start a client docker container to create a bucket with a file and set it to public.
```
docker run -it --network=host --entrypoint=/bin/sh minio/mc
/ # mc config host rm local
/ # mc config host add local http://127.0.0.1:9000 minioadmin minioadmin
/ # mc mb local/testbucket
/ # mc policy set public local/testbucket
/ # mc cp /data/file local/testbucket/path/to/file
```
3. Disconnect your network or have a corporate proxy
4. Try to access the file:
```python
client = Minio(
    '127.0.0.1:9000',
    secure=False
)

buffer = client.get_object('testbucket', 'path/to/file')
```

## Workaround

Just initialize with creds without the `IamEc2MetaData` provider:

```python
client = Minio(
    '127.0.0.1:9000',
    secure=False,
    credentials=Credentials(
        provider= Chain(
            providers=[
                Static(access_key, secret_key, session_token),
                EnvAWS(),
                EnvMinio(),
            ]
        )
    )
)
```

It actually blocks the program for like 2 mins when `self._credentials.get()` is called, which happens twice for a single `get_object` call.

items.title: AWS IAM Credential using subscripts on not subscriptable objects
items.body:
When trying to use the IamEc2MetaData provider like this:
```
from minio import Minio
from minio.credentials import IamEc2MetaData, Credentials

# Initialize Minio with IamEc2MetaData default credentials object
client = Minio('s3.amazonaws.com',
               credentials=Credentials(provider=IamEc2MetaData()))


buckets = client.list_buckets()
```
I got the following error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 10, in <module>
    client.list_buckets()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/minio/api.py", line 411, in list_buckets
    raise AccessDenied(response)
minio.error.AccessDenied: AccessDenied: message: Access Denied
```

After doing some digging on why my credentials were not working I found the root cause:

IamEc2MetaData provider is trying to access http response data and status using subscripts throwing the following error:
```
TypeError: 'HTTPResponse' object is not subscriptable
```

items.title: put_object should support file-like objects with an undefined length

I've structured my code to produce a file-like object which dynamically generates its contents as its being read. I would like to avoid generating the object upfront to measure its length, because it could be rather large and I don't have anywhere to put it. I don't want to generate it twice, measuring and discarding the first time, then uploading it the second time, because it could change during this time and generating this object is a computationally expensive process.

Instead, I should be able to put_objects with an undefined length, and specify the chunk size manually.

items.title: [Feature request] More explicit memory management for object uploads
items.body:
Currently the `put_object` method might be quite memory demanding in some situations and this is not very obvious. For example the minimal part size is 5 MiB and the `_do_stream_upload` method uses the private pool to perform partial uploads with private hardcoded max workers value of 3 (the `_PARALLEL_UPLOADERS` constant). This means that a single object upload process would take minimum 15 MiB of RAM for data objects whose size is >= 15MiB. In reality this number would be greater (perhaps, about 20 MiB if we also count the size of all the helper objects). 

I assume this should be at least mentioned somewhere in the documentation. Also it would be nice to have a possibility to control the multipart upload process deeper, so there would be no unexpected memory usage spikes.

items.title: What is the proper way to cancel a running file upload?
items.body:
Hello,

in our client code we'd like to cancel the file upload to minio storage after it has already been started. My question is whether there is any appropriate method to do that, since the current implementation only exposes the `put_object` method, which incapsulates `_stream_put_object`?

Also, there is no callback/pipe object available, which could be used to interrupt the running upload process (or at least we were not able to find such). Currently, we simply asynchronously schedule the deletion of file from the bucket after the upload is completed, which is suboptimal. Thanks in advance for your response.

items.title: Create option for ignoring S3 naming rules
items.body:
Minio supports exposing existing datasets on NAS (for the NAS gateway function).  The data that's already there, especially if it was created in a Windows environment, but certainly possible in a Linux environment, likely isn't going to conform to S3 standards- meaning it will likely have capital letters, or symbols that don't adhere to the standard. 

It would be MOST useful if there was a "relaxed" setting that allowed more, if not all, POSIX-compliant file and directory names to be used, specifically for API calls. 

I.E. My NAS has a directory of testing data called "WindowsUpdateLogs".  That's not compliant.  But when I start Minio against that directory, the browser shows it fine and will serve it up fine. 

Performing a list_buckets() from Python shows the bucket with the "invalid" name.  But if I try to list the objects in that bucket, it errors out as the bucket name I've passed is... invalid.  So that's a problem. 

Any ideas? or am I right to be requesting this as an RFE?

items.title: fget_object() creates temporary file in `append` mode
items.body:
Hi.

1. Method `fget_object()` creates temporary file in append (`ab`) mode with stable name.
That means, if you've received an error (e.g. `InvalidSizeError`) and decided to retry, the new object will be appended to previously invalid object. As a result -- invalid object with no error.
2. I propose to overwrite previously created file.

Of course there are alternatives: for example to create real temp autodeleting file with temp name.

items.title: Use Credentials (similar to minio-go) to enable AWS IAM
items.body:
At [codecov.io](https://www.codecov.io) we use minio-py for our on-prem enterprise solution. Our customers have expressed the need of being able to authenticate to AWS using IAM in order to make key rotation much more efficient.

I noticed that there was some kind of effort to add this functionality to the minio-py repository about two years ago.

See issue [#502](https://github.com/minio/minio-py/issues/502) 
See closed PR [#507](https://github.com/minio/minio-py/pull/507/files) 

I also noticed that other minio SDK have this functionality (Eg. [minio-go](https://github.com/minio/minio-go)) and I think would be nice and valuable to have this functionality in the python SDK as well.

I started making changes using PR [#507](https://github.com/minio/minio-py/pull/507/files) and minio-go PR [#646](https://github.com/minio/minio-go/pull/646/files?file-filters%5B%5D=#diff-2f280fb058ba01353aed10f15c61f848L3) as reference. 
It would be great if I can get your feedback on the changes I have done so far trying to add Credentials functionality. I would be more than happy to get all of your guys feedback and modify the changes accordingly.

Link to the changes I have made so far:
https://github.com/minio/minio-py/compare/master...febg:fb_credentials

items.title: Broken URL link in minio/error.py
items.body:
# Problem
The link to AWS' S3 errors (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/ErrorResponses.htmlRESTErrorResponses) is broken on [line 266 of minio/error.py](https://github.com/minio/minio-py/blob/master/minio/error.py#L266).

# Solution
It is simply missing a '#', i.e. it should be https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/ErrorResponses.html#RESTErrorResponses.

items.title: `sign_v4` should always add `X-Amz-Content-Sha256` header
items.body: Currently, `sign_v4` sets the `X-Amz-Content-Sha256` header to 'UNSIGNED-PAYLOAD' when the request is going over HTTPS. However, as can be seen by running `mc --debug`, this header should always be set to the actual digest. I have not tested if the minio server enforces this requirement for all endpoints, but it does appear to enforce it for the admin endpoints (or at least for `minio/admin/v1/add-canned-policy`). Though, admittedly, the admin endpoints do not appear to be supported by this library, currently (hence why I'm writing my own API calls, and why I ran into this bug in `sign_v4`).

items.title: Setting region='us-east-1' breaks `get_object` when the URL is not `localhost`
items.body:
### Summary
I believe I found a bug while writing unit tests for a custom Python library that uses the minio-py SDK to talk to a MinIO server. Setting `region='us-east-1'` in the Minio constructor generates a `TypeError` in the urllib3 method `urlopen` call made by the minio-py API's `_url_open` method when the host name is not on the same host (e.g. `localhost`). The exact error message is provided in the Traceback section below.

This issue is present regardless of:
- the scheme being HTTP or HTTPS
- passing in a `urllib3.poolmanager.PoolManager` as the `http_client` to the Minio constructor
- passing in a `urllib3.Retry` object with or without `redirect=False`, `remove_headers_on_redirect=False`, `remove_headers_on_redirect=frozenset([])`, or `remove_headers_on_redirect=None` 

The apparent solutions are either:
- Don't pass `region` to the Minio constructor
- Use a `localhost` hostname (appears that this causes `conn.is_same_host(redirect_location)` to return `False` in urllib3's `urlopen` method in poolmanager.py)

### Details
Python version: 3.7.3
MinIO version: 4.0.18
urllib3 version: 1.23, 1.25.3 (tested under both)
OS & kernel: Ubuntu 16.04.1 4.15.0-51-generic

### Traceback
(edited for brevity)
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/long/bazelpath/object_storage_test.runfiles/org_pypi_minio/minio/api.py", line 672, in get_object
    sse=sse)
  File "/long/bazelpath/object_storage_test.runfiles/org_pypi_minio/minio/api.py", line 1487, in _get_partial_object
    preload_content=False)
  File "/long/bazelpath/object_storage_test.runfiles/org_pypi_minio/minio/api.py", line 1872, in _url_open
    preload_content=preload_content)
  File "/long/bazelpath/object_storage_test.runfiles/org_pypi_urllib3/urllib3/poolmanager.py", line 345, in urlopen
    kw['headers'].pop(header, None)
TypeError: pop() takes 2 positional arguments but 3 were given
```

items.title: Conda packaging
items.body:
Please make minio-py available for installation with [conda](https://docs.conda.io/en/latest/).

Apart from being an easy way to install minio-py for use by developers, it enables software that depends on minio-py to be made available using conda (see, e.g. https://github.com/datajoint/datajoint-python/issues/293 )

Packaging could either be done by: 
1) Building the package during CI, then hosting it in a custom channel at anaconda.org (which can then be installed with `conda install -c minio minio`)
2) Creating a feedstock at conda-forge, which will result in conda packages being automatically built by their CI and posted at anaconda.org. (They can then be installed with `conda install -c conda-forge minio`)

The latter has the advantage of being quite trivial--you essentially just use conda-forge to wrap the pip package--but it would require that the version of the feedstock at conda-forge be manually bumped as part of the release process.

A [search on anaconda.org for minio](https://anaconda.org/search?q=minio) shows that at one point a couple years ago someone was building packages for minio-server and minio-client, but those have not been maintained.

Since conda can be cross-language, and can be used to install all sorts of stuff, it may be advisable to call the package `minio-py`, rather than just `minio`. (Although it is mostly used for python  package distribution, so it could also be a good idea to give it the same name as the pip package, i.e. `minio`.)

items.title: allow `copy_object` with `content-type` in metadata
items.body:
Trying to use `copy_object` to copy an object from one bucket to another.

To keep the target object well functional, I need to preserve `Content-Type` and `Content-Encoding` headers.

`Content-Encoding` is possible passing it's value via `metadata`.

However, I did not succeed with `Content-Type`.

The only solution was to edit sources of [minio/helpers.py](https://github.com/minio/minio-py/blob/master/minio/helpers.py#L667) function `is_supported_header` adding value "content-type".

```python
# returns true if a standard supported header
def is_supported_header(key):
    ## Supported headers for object.
    supported_headers = [
       "cache-control",
       "content-encoding",
       "content-type",  # added one
       "content-disposition",
       "content-language",
       "x-amz-website-redirect-location",
            ## Add more supported headers here.
        ]
    return key.lower() in supported_headers
```

This might be the solution, but I am not sure, it does not break anything else.

items.title: get_object doesn't return the object if the path does not starts with slash "/"
items.body:
Inconsistent behavior between minio sdk get_object and boto3 s3 get_object

## To reproduce the issue:
use object_name without a slash
get_object(bucket, "directory/dummy.file").read()
it will return 0 bytes, while if you tried using slash
get_object(bucket, "/directory/dummy.file").read()
it works

## In s3 SDK, it works with both scenarios
s3_client.get_object(Bucket=bucket, Key="directory/dummy.file")["Body"].read()
s3_client.get_object(Bucket=bucket, Key="/directory/dummy.file")["Body"].read()

items.title: Minio Python SDK doesn't support "/" as a key
items.body:
The SDK does not support having a file with a key ends with "/". This operation is known for creating a virtual directory.

## To reproduce the issue:
content = BytesIO(b"")
put_object(bucket=bucket_name, path="dummyfolder/", data=content, length=0)

## Error:
minio.error.ResponseError: ResponseError: code: XMinioInvalidObjectName, message: Object name contains unsupported characters., bucket_name: ata, object_name: dummyfolder/, request_id: ....

If you tried the same operation using s3 boto python SDK, it works fine
s3_client.put_object(Bucket=bucket_name, Key="dummyfolder/", Body=b"")

items.title: Minio Python SDK doesn't support touch operation
items.body:
The SDK does not support uploading a file with zero content length, this operation is used to touch files or create a virtual directory.

To reproduce the issue:
--------------------------
content = BytesIO(b"")
put_object(bucket_name=bucket_name, object_name="dummyfile", data=content, length=0)

Error:
------
minio.error.SignatureDoesNotMatch: SignatureDoesNotMatch: message: The request signature we calculated does not match the signature you provided.

If you tried the same operation using s3 boto python SDK, it works fine
s3_client.put_object(Bucket=bucket_name, Key="dummyfile", Body=b"")

items.title: Add tests to source distribution
items.body: Please add the tests to the sdist, and ideally any extra steps needed for `setup.py test` to work, to make it easier to package and test it.

items.title: Customizable metadata JSON encoder
items.body:
An "TypeError: expected string or bytes-like object" is raised if I pass `metadata={'None': None}` to `fput_object`. To bypass this error, you would have to map None as "null". However, the desired encoding would be `{"None": null}` which is not possible in the current implementation ("null" != null).

Same error is raised when passing nested metadata, such as `{'foo': 'bar', 'system_info': {'orange': 'apple'}}`

See [json.JSONEncoder](https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/json.html#json.JSONEncoder) for reference.

items.title: SignatureDoesNotMatch with multipart upload to Ceph radosgw
items.body:
We are using minio-py to upload files to our S3 server (Ceph radosgw). Uploading files over 5MiB fails with `SignatureDoesNotMatch`. 

The following code is enough to reproduce the issue with Python 3.6.6, Ceph 12.2.8 and minio-py 4.0.8:

```python
import os
from minio import Minio

client = Minio('rgw.vis.ethz.ch',
                access_key='<our access key>',
                secret_key='<our secret key>',
                secure=True)

fname = '<path to some local file larger than 5MiB>'
with open(fname, 'rb') as file_data:
        file_stat = os.stat(fname)
        client.put_object('<our bucket name>', '<some remote path>', file_data,
                        file_stat.st_size, content_type='<some content type>')
```

It fails with the following stacktrace:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/philippe/temp/minio-py-debug/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/minio/api.py", line 1555, in _stream_put_object
    upload_result = pool.result()
  File "/home/philippe/temp/minio-py-debug/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/minio/thread_pool.py", line 92, in result
    raise self.exceptions_queue.get()
  File "/home/philippe/temp/minio-py-debug/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/minio/thread_pool.py", line 57, in run
    result = func(*args, **kargs)
  File "/home/philippe/temp/minio-py-debug/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/minio/api.py", line 1502, in _upload_part_routine
    upload_id, part_number, sse=sse)
  File "/home/philippe/temp/minio-py-debug/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/minio/api.py", line 1491, in _do_put_object
    content_sha256=sha256_hex
  File "/home/philippe/temp/minio-py-debug/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/minio/api.py", line 1832, in _url_open
    object_name).get_exception()
minio.error.SignatureDoesNotMatch: SignatureDoesNotMatch: message: The request signature we calculated does not match the signature you provided.

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 14, in <module>
    file_stat.st_size, content_type='application/pdf')
  File "/home/philippe/temp/minio-py-debug/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/minio/api.py", line 782, in put_object
    data, length, metadata=metadata, sse=sse)
  File "/home/philippe/temp/minio-py-debug/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/minio/api.py", line 1561, in _stream_put_object
    upload_id)
  File "/home/philippe/temp/minio-py-debug/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/minio/api.py", line 1618, in _remove_incomplete_upload
    headers={})
  File "/home/philippe/temp/minio-py-debug/.venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/minio/api.py", line 1832, in _url_open
    object_name).get_exception()
minio.error.SignatureDoesNotMatch: SignatureDoesNotMatch: message: The request signature we calculated does not match the signature you provided.
```

The issue does not occur with files smaller than 5 MiB. The issue does not occur when using Minio as the S3 server. The issue does not occur when uploading files to radosgw through the Minio CLI.

I have filed a [corresponding issue in Ceph](https://tracker.ceph.com/issues/37616).

items.title: copyobject API doesn't support metadata
items.body: copyobject API doesn't support "metadata" arg which is part of S3 specifications. It is worth to mention that it is already supported in the other SDKs.

items.title: Add parameter to ListObjectsV2 to make the iteration interruptible
items.body:
Hi guys

Currently the `ListObjectsV2` in SDK is not able to start a iteration in halfway, for some small cases it is ok. But in my project, a bucket have over 100k items, if any failing happened,  I have to re-start the whole iteration from the first item, it is really unacceptable for a large bucket

According to discussion of [issue 6825](https://github.com/minio/minio/issues/6825), go lang core API already had a `start-after` parameter, I think the SDK should support this too, for example:

``` python
objects = minioClient.list_objects_v2('mybucket', prefix='my-prefixname',
                              recursive=True)
for obj in objects:
    last_cursor = obj.cursor
```

if iteration failed, input cursor as `startAfter` will continue last task:

``` js
objects = minioClient.list_objects_v2('mybucket', prefix='my-prefixname',
                              recursive=True, start_cursor=last_cursor)
```

Looking forward for this feature, this is really important, thanks.

items.title: Some gaps in the documentation
items.body:
I have a hard time finding information about some of the information found in the Python Client API docs:

- `get_object()` returns an `urllib3.response.HTTPResponse` object, while `fget_object` returns an object that contains a lot of extra information (like `stat_object()` does). I am guessing that this info is also included in the HTTP response header when using `get_object()`, but the docs don't say. Is there a way to parse this into a stat()-like object, or will I have to make a separate API call using `stat_object()`?

- The docs for `list_objects()` mention querying by prefix, but I don't find any further information on the concept, and performance impact, of doing that. I also checked the rest of the Minio documentation, but found nothing useful.

- Similarly, how does the .is_dir attribute work? How do you create an object that is a directory? And it mentions prefixes in the same documentation, so how do those relate do directories?

- Is there any way to query on metadata?

- What's an etag? Is it a unique ID for an objects? And if so, how can I get an object based on that?

- Is there a way to query based on content_type?

Any help would be appreciated.

items.title: "ListObjectV2Result" XML is not parsable - probably due to non UTF-8 characters
items.body:
When trying to get a full listing of objects in a bucket...

```
minio.error.InvalidXMLError: InvalidXMLError: message: "ListObjectV2Result" XML is not parsable. Message: reference to invalid character number: line 2, column 112949
```
This appears very similar to the explanation given in the s3cmd tool issue comment:
  https://github.com/s3tools/s3cmd/issues/758#issuecomment-406899282

If there are invalid UTF-8 characters in the file names... is there anything minio-py can do to handle this cleanly?

items.title: make_bucket: Specifying a non standard region fails with AWS S3
items.body:
Running the code below will fail (notice the region parameter)

```
from minio import Minio
from minio.error import ResponseError

client = Minio('s3.amazonaws.com',
               access_key='YOUR-ACCESSKEYID',
               secret_key='YOUR-SECRETACCESSKEY')

# Make a new bucket
try:
    client.make_bucket('my-bucketname', 'us-west-1')
except ResponseError as err:
    print(err)
```
